title: What is new in the Brexit deal and what has changed?
text:
Boris Johnson says he has abolished the Northern Irish Backstop in his new Brexit deal (Picture: Getty)

Boris Johnson has secured a new Brexit deal less than two weeks before the UK is due to leave the EU.

It means the UK could be leaving the bloc on different terms to those in former PM Theresa May’s Withdrawal Agreement.

MPs now have two days to mull over the content of the new deal before a vote in the House of Commons on Saturday.

But what’s new in Boris Johnson’s deal?

Northern Irish Backstop

ITV’s Robert Preston has tweeted a breakdown of what Downing Street say are the main points of the new deal.

Attached is how a Downing Street source is selling the deal struck by @BorisJohnson. But we don’t have the legal text yet. And I don’t have to tell you what that means! pic.twitter.com/veRDPMAYj9 — Robert Peston (@Peston) October 17, 2019

Advertisement

Advertisement

Crucially, Boris Johnson has scrapped the controversial Northern Irish Backstop that many argued tied the UK to the EU indefinitely.

Under the new deal, Northern Ireland will be in the UK customs territory ‘forever’ and will benefit from any free trade deals the UK strikes.

However there will be a ‘special arrangement’ for Northern Ireland, ‘reflecting the unique circumstances there’.

There will be no hard border between the two Irelands, as Northern Ireland will have access to the single market while being part of the UK customs territory.

This will be underpinned by the principle of ‘democratic consent’, and Northern Ireland will have the ability to leave the arrangement through a vote in the NI Assembly.

The anti-democratic backstop has been abolished. The people of Northern Ireland will be in charge of the laws that they live by, and – unlike the backstop – will have the right to end the special arrangement if they so choose. #GetBrexitDone #TakeBackControl — Boris Johnson (@BorisJohnson) October 17, 2019

‘Take back control’

Critics of Theresa May’s Withdrawal Agreement said it essentially tied the UK to EU laws without giving the country any influence over them.

Analysts say that while much of the new deal is unchanged, a key difference is the trading relationship the UK will have with the EU after Brexit.

The new deal has scrapped the UK’s commitment to a ‘single customs territory’, confirming the need for checks at the border.

Under the new arrangement, goods will not attract tariffs if they satisfy ‘rules of origin’ checks.

Advertisement

ITV’s Joel Hills says this will make some UK/EU trade more costly.

Political Declaration is out. Much of it is unchanged but gone is commitment to “a trading relationship on goods that is as close as possible”. Instead a “free trade agreement”. This matters. Higher trade barriers = greater economic cost. pic.twitter.com/C3D2fbMg2T — Joel Hills (@ITVJoel) October 17, 2019

Barnier confirms that it’s out with the common customs territory, instead the UK and EU will pursue a free trade agreement without tariffs and quotas. May wanted frictionless trade, Johnson is happy to live with a little more friction. — Joel Hills (@ITVJoel) October 17, 2019

Downing Street has said the new deal has ended the supremacy of the European Court in Britain, and ensured Britain will no longer be bound by EU laws and taxes.

This means the UK will be able to change laws in a ‘huge number of areas, from product standards to fishing rules’.

It also means the UK can strike its own free trade deals ‘all around the world’ and change VAT and other tax rules currently determined by Brussels.

However, the government have not published details of the legal text to back up any of the new arrangements in Boris Johnson’s deal.

Boris Johnson leaves Downing Street for Brussels after securing a new Brexit deal: (Picture: GETTY IMAGES)

What’s next?

The next challenge for Johnson will be getting approval in the British Parliament, particularly from Northern Ireland’s Democratic Union Party.

Advertisement

The DUP – critical to the Tory coalition – have already said they do not support it.

Labour have already called it a ‘sell-out deal’ with leader Jeremy Corbyn saying there should be a second referendum so that voters get the final say.

He said the new deal was worse than the one Theresa May negotiated, which was rejected by Westminster three times.

MPs will vote on the deal in Parliament on Saturday.
description: What is new in the Brexit deal and what has changed?
